content.description: A route worth writing home about. Scramble to the base of the sharp arete. From the right side of the arete, follow three bolts along the arete. At the third bolt, perch along the arete to gain the thin crack. Ascend the thin crack (crux, finger/tips size cams) and mantle onto the ledge. Lower from mussy hook anchor on the ledge. Please do not climb above the anchors in this sector, the stacked blocks above defy logic, and significant rock fall is a potential hazard here.
content.location: Follow the current approach trail. Writing Home follows the striking low arete and crack system on the left side of a large right-facing corner system located where the approach trail meets the base of the wall.

climbs.name: Wildling
climbs.fa: Alden Pellett, Ryan Stefiuk, Kristin Dolcimascolo, 2021

content.description: Heading uphill from the Launch Pad, locate the huge right-facing flake which is the start to Wilding. P1: 5.9. Lie-back the flake (5.5?) up to the obvious 15-foot finger traverse. Smear your feet across to a good rest stance before launching up the left-leaning hand crack. Climb this to a ledge with anchors out right.P2: 5.8 or 5.5. Climb directly up, just left of the anchor to the spacious ledge. Pad up the short slab to the right-facing corner onto the face. climb face, jug holds and cracks. Then make a more exposed traverse right past gear toward the top. Finish past a single bolt to the anchors. (To keep the grade easier on the top pitch, go left and climb the easy crack to the spacious ledge and belay again in the long flake under the roof or climb to this point on the first pitch. This will also avoid rope drag when taking the easier line on P2.)

climbs.name: Queen of Dragons
climbs.fa: Kristin Dolcimascolo, Alden Pellett, Ryan Stefiuk, 2021

content.description: Bolt-protected mantle moves lead to an overhang with a crack. Pull around this into a wide hand crack. Jam up to a horizontal. Pull out left to a thin crack and follow this to the ledge. Tree anchor.
content.protection: Bolts to start. Trad gear above.
content.location: Just past the Cleft, before the rockfall zone, is an obvious face on the left with two bolts.

content.description: Right of Castle Black. Fun thoughtful climbing starting in the corner and then out left onto the face. Finishes up slab to the anchors on Castle Black. Shorter climbers are advised to consider stick clipping the first bolt.
content.location: This route starts in the corner 20 feet right of Castle Black.

climbs.name: Little Averill
climbs.fa: Dustin Dearborn, Tim Mclaughlin, Rob Niles

content.description:
Climb the central weakness up the middle of the face past a stump and a series of vertical and horizontal cracks to a communal anchor. 

  Var 1: The arête left of the main face.  A short crux midway leads to large horizontals near the top. (5.9) 

  Var 2: The steeper right hand arête with a low crux.  Be mindful with protection. (5.8) 

Note: After extensive cleaning of the cracks, Dustin noticed sawed off branches low on a spruce tree above the wall, indicating the route(s) may have been previously top roped.
content.location: The short south facing wall at the end of the approach trail, just left of a narrow gulley.

climbs.name: The Cleft
climbs.fa: Tim McLaughlin, Dustin Dearborn, Rob Niles

content.description: Climb up into the back of the obvious, dark chimney, climbing surprisingly clean and featured rock with good protection, to a tree covered ledge, two thirds of the way up the cliff.
content.location: 15 feet right of Button Buck, climbing the chimney where the block separates from the main cliff.

content.description: Catamount Corners,  2 pitches.  P1: 5.10a/b PG. Climb directly to the second bolt or weave an easier line right, up, back left. step up to the corner, tiptoe to place gear as high as possible and make a committing move (crux) into the lieback corner. Exit the corner out right at the birch tree (**I may cut this tree out) to a ledge. smear up to and into the next beautiful finger crack in the beautiful corner. Pass a giant scary flake at the top to reach the big flat ledge and a 2-bolt anchor. P2: 5.9+. Climb the corners on the left above to the trees.
content.protection: Bolt anchor at ledge. Tree at top.
content.location: On the far right of the initial wall after the trail heads downhill a little, is an easier slab below obvious corner system above. It can be started from the bottom without protection or traversed into higher from the left out to the first bolt.

climbs.name: Castle Black
climbs.fa: Alden Pellett, Ryan Stefiuk, Kristin Dolcimascolo, 2021

content.description: A fun classic line with slab, face and steep crack climbing. In the center of the tallest open part of the cliff, 50 feet right of "Writing Home" out on the main face after the trail takes a big step up, look for a small corner with a bolt 10 feet up. Start up this slab to a short steeper face and make a harder face move to an easy slab gaining an anchor at the base of the steeper upper wall. From the anchor, climb a crack in the large block on the left to a stance, clip a bolt and launch up the steep layback into a corner crack system. Follow this through an overhang to the upper part. From a good small rest ledge, finish on the overhanging hand crack to a 2-bolt anchor at the very top.
content.protection: A few bolts plus cams from 1/2" to 3.5" and a couple of nuts around 1/2".

climbs.name: Button Buck
climbs.fa: Rob Niles, Tim Mclaughlin, Dustin Dearborn

content.description: A quality, moderate finger crack. We just wish it went higher. The crux is off the ground and then cruiser to the anchor.
content.location: Obvious finger crack in the first bit of solid rock 20' left of the apocalyptic rock fall scene.

content.description: Black Mountain North is a small area to the left of a large rock fall visible form the road under the power line. You will drive past Black Mountain North on your way to the main cliff.
